m:properties.d:SessionName: Improve distributed system and web app performance by using in-memory cache (Redis) system
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
Applications often integrate with APIs for the purpose of retrieving data from a disk-based storage system like SQL Server. This poses challenges due slow queries and amount of data sent down the wire. In this presentation, we discuss the performance concerns with this type of architecture especially for big data scenarios. Oscar Garcia shows how to address those concerns by following a series of steps in which an application is refactored with minimum changes to support an in-memory data store and data streaming. We start by discussing the challenges when using data queries. We structure the data for in in-memory storage. We replace the API requests with real-time data streaming.
Learning Objectives:
SQL Server Query Challenges
Redis Cache Basic Operations and Structure
Angular App with Socket.io integration
Node.js Backend with Socket.io and Redis support
Real-time data integration

m:properties.d:SessionName: Become a Power BI superstar under 1 hour !
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: Power BI is Microsoft's industry leading data analytics discovery and visualization tool that has disrupted the way data professionals interact and derive insights from their data. It is one of the most in-demand and sought-after tools to know in today's IT career market. Join us for a fun and interactive learning opportunity to learn how to ingest, transform and visualize data from a wide variety of sources using Power BI. Learn how to create rich and interactive reports incorporating slicers, drill-down and drill-through actions. Attendees will also learn how to create, publish and share reports and dashboards for desktop and mobile consumption. Attendees will walk-away feeling like real Power BI *superstars, capable of tackling any data project in their paths! *Awesomeness may vary.

m:properties.d:SessionName: An Introduction to Azure Data Studio
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: This session will provide a high level overview of Azure Data Studio and highlight some of the differences from SQL Server Management Studio. We cover saved connections, how to get both the actual and estimated Execution plans, workspaces and one of my favorite features, Notebooks. We also go over what an extension is and why I would want to use them.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Is my Server having Memory Pressure and how do I find the source
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: As we all know, SQL Server loves memory and will use as much as it can get. However, when there is memory pressure we need to use our DBA skills to identify what is causing the pressure. During this session we will explore how SQL Server uses memory and how to properly configure memory settings. We will discuss the use of DMVs and other tools to help us find what is consuming the most memory and some potential solutions.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Temporal Tables - Managing Large Data Sets and Their Effects on Performance
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: So, you installed SQL 2016 (or newer) and implemented Temporal Tables for some of your data. Everything is running well, but now what? In this session we will look at the effects of adding various indexes to both the main and the history table and discuss what that might mean to the front end performance. We will go into data management scenarios, for when you do not want to keep all the data in that table forever.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Build a Modern Data Warehouse with Apache Spark and SQL Server
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
A data warehouse (DW) is a core component of business intelligence and a central data repository for different sources. This poses many challenges as the schema definition for those sources may be completely different from one another. In this presentation, we discuss how to create a data warehouse model that can support data from multiple systems. Oscar Garcia shows how to build a dimensional model which can enable us to import the data with different shapes into a data warehouse. We then create processes to transform and load the data using Apache Spark. We finally use Power BI to visualize the data from our data warehouse and Spark.
Learning Objectives:
Challenges when using disparate data sources (different models)
Define a common model to support the different model shapes (Star Schema)
Apache Spark Overview
Strategy for loading the different data-sets into the common model
Data analysis and visualization with Power BI

m:properties.d:SessionName: What's New in SQL Server 2019: 100% Demos
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
You haven't installed SQL Server 2019 yet, and you don't want to sit through a bunch of slides. You want to see a series of real-world demos focusing on the features of SQL Server 2019 that will make your users happier with as little work as possible on your part. You don't have time to rewrite all your queries or learn new languages - you just want the database to go faster.
I'm Brent Ozar, and I'll give you the whirlwind tour. I'll focus on just the features that make the biggest bang for the buck, things you can implement right away and see a noticeable difference. I'll show you what kinds of code will benefit the most so you can go back to the office and have an honest discussion with management about what to expect.
No slides here - not even an about-me slide. Let's dive into some queries!

m:properties.d:SessionName: Dynamic SQL: When, Why, and How to Use It
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
You're comfortable writing T-SQL, and you've built a lot of stored procedures that have a bunch of parameters. For example, you have that "product search" stored proc with parameters for product category, name, price range, sort order, etc, and you have to accept any of 'em.
So how do we make those go fast? And how can we get 'em to use indexes?
In one all-demo hour, performance tuner Brent Ozar will show you several ways that fail in comically bad ways. You'll learn how to write dynamic SQL that's easy to tune, manage, and troubleshoot.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Why is the Same Query Sometimes Slow?
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
You swear nothing has changed, but all of a sudden, out of nowhere, queries that used to be fast are suddenly slow. Even weirder, you take the slow query from the application, run it in SSMS, and it's totally fast! What's going on? You restart SQL Server or update statistics, and the problem seems to go away - but only for a few days or weeks, and then it comes right back. You're familiar enough with execution plans to realize that you're getting different plans, but...why? And how do you fix it long term?
In this session, you'll see live demos of the most common culprit: parameter sniffing. You'll learn how to recognize parameter sniffing when it strikes, understand what causes it, see how to fix it short term with the lowest impact possible, and learn 7 ways to fix it long term.
To get the most out of this session, you should have already watched the free online class How to Think Like the Engine, and be familiar with using SET STATISTICS IO ON to see logical reads.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Intro to Query Store
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
In this session, we will look at the new Query Store feature in SQL Server 2016, 2017, and 2019. Query Store tracks changes in execution plans, allowing you to easily view performance differences and revert to older plans with a few clicks of the mouse in 2016.
Then in 2017, Microsoft added wait stats per query plan and Automatic Plan Correction capabilities. Allowing DBAs more tools to troubleshoot fires with and a way to automatically resolve issues.
In this session, we will walk through the features of the Query Store, so you can understand how to use them in SQL Server 2016, 2017, and 2019.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Azure Data Events and Storage
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: In this *updated* demo filled session we will investigate the various data storage options that are presented for developers in the Microsoft Azure Cloud. We will cover data movement by responding to events in Azure storage. Topics will include Logic Apps, Data Factory, blob storage, Azure Search, CosmosDb, and Azure Sql Database.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Welcome to Azure Synapse
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: Microsoft's powerful new service, Azure Synapse, brings together the worlds of data warehousing and big data analytics by providing a unified experience for ingesting, cleansing, modeling, and sharing data. In this session, we'll discuss the basics of Azure Synapse, ideal uses cases for Azure Synapse, and demonstrate how attendees can use Azure Synapse. By the conclusion of this session, attendees will have a deeper understanding of Azure Synapse and how to begin using Azure Synapse.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Power Apps and Power BI Better Together
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: The Microsoft Power Platform combines intuitive business ready applications that help make you more efficient at your job. While these tools can build amazing solutions on their own, when you combine them together you are able to solve much more advanced problems. In this session you will learn how to embed Power Apps in your Power BI Reports to support complex business problems like writeback to your data sources.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Red Flags and Red Herrings in the Execution Plans
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
Performance tuning of the complex queries is a challenging task. You may see many operators in the execution plan and it is often hard to choose where to start optimization. To make matter worse, it is impossible to define the strategy that can be applied to all tuning opportunities. For example, the Key Lookup operator may represent significant issues in some cases and be completely normal in others.
In this session, Dmitri demonstrates the set of patterns that represent performance issues in the execution plans. You will learn how to see the red flags and ignore the red herrings during query tuning.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Database Design Fundamentals
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: Data should be easy to work with in SQL Server if the database has been organized as close as possible to the standards of normalization that have been proven for many years, but are often thought of as old-fashioned. Many common T-SQL programming "difficulties" are the result of struggling against these standards and can be avoided by understanding the requirements, applying normalization, as well as a healthy dose of simple common sense. In this session I will give an overview of how to design a relational database, allowing you to work with the data structures instead of against them. This will let you use SQL naturally, enabling the query engine internals to optimize your output needs without you needing to spend a lot of time thinking about it. This will mean less time trying to figure out why SUBSTRING(column,3,1) = 'A' is killing your performance, and more time for solving the next customer problem.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Finally!, I can keep my SQL Environment Current using SQL 2019!
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
How many times have you had to beg, plead, push, pull, and drag your vendors or even your own IT organization just to try to keep your environment within extended support? How many times have you had that you know some new instance level feature or improvement would greatly improve your workload, yet you are stuck months out from getting the software to certify compatibility with that new version?
With SQL 2019, many of these problem become problems of the past. Sure there is work to do, but with SQL 2019, Microsoft has moved to certifying database compatibility levels and SQL 2019 supports and will upgrade compatibility level 100 (SQL 2008/2008R2) and greater.
In this session we will discuss the new model, what it can mean to your organization, and go through some of the advantages of running the newer version with even really old compatibility levels.

m:properties.d:SessionName: How to Give Your Coworkers the Bird...and Thrive!!
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
A key skill required in today’s competitive IT world, is the ability to evaluate and react appropriately to the variety of personalities we are exposed to every day. Managers, vendors, subordinates, and customers...all take a deft touch in how we communicate and respond to their personal and professional styles.
I’ll show you how you can put most individuals into one of four “bird” groups. Once you can see these dispositions for what they truly are, you can easily design a strategy to get the absolute most from your interactions. Your success relies on your ability to be flexible on how you interact with the various types of birds. It’s not only very powerful, but extremely effortless, and a real “hoot” once you start using it.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Instant SQL Sandbox Using Docker
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: SQL Server running on Linux was unthinkable ten years ago. Now it is not only possible to run SQL Server on Linux, but also Windows 10 as the sandbox and development machines that can host SQL Server on Linux. It is possible because of a Container technology. Using Azure Data Studio's notebook as the runbook, we will show step by step to deploy SQL Server on Docker in Windows 10 desktop . The demo will also show the experimental feature of LCOW (Linux Container on Windows).

m:properties.d:SessionName: Relational Design Critique
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: The process of designing a relational database is not overly complex, and may be done by almost anyone on the development team. The process requires one to take the time to understand the requirements, when they exist, and apply a straightforward set of transforms to produce table structures that meets the needs. The tough part is that the process requires time and experience, neither of which anyone has enough of. In this session, to help the attendee differentiate right-enough designs from overly simple or overly complex designs, we will look at a variety of database snippets, each inspired from a real life design. We will discuss the pros and cons of the approach taken, and consider possible remediations to learn from a failure that was made by someone else.

m:properties.d:SessionName: Communicate Back And Forth In Your SSIS Packages
m:properties.d:SessionDescription: Dynamically configure your packages for any environment and make them "talk" to each other. With this concept in mind you can solve quite complex enterprise issues with low maintenance overhead

m:properties.d:SessionName: Why Defragmenting Your Indexes Isn't Helping
m:properties.d:SessionDescription:
For years, you've heard that you're supposed to reorganize your indexes to make SQL Server go faster. It sounds like it makes sense - keep things in order, right? But you keep doing it, and SQL Server isn't getting any faster. You've even heard that setting fill factor will help prevent fragmentation, and you're doing that too - but your indexes still keep getting fragmented every day, and users aren't happy with performance.
This advice made a lot of sense at the turn of the century, but today, things are different - and we're not just talking solid state drives. In just 15 minutes, you'll have a series of ah-ha moments when you realize that your daily index maintenance jobs might just be making the problem worse instead of better.
